info.game_comments: Battle of the Decades: The 1990s game 5.

(1, 1).clue: 4 of her books, including "The Bluest Eye", made the club

(3, 1).clue: An old spider's home up in the corner of the attic

(4, 1).clue: In 1999 this Denver QB quit while he was way ahead after 16 seasons & more than 51,000 passing yards

(5, 1).clue: "Guilty At Last", said the Times when this don was convicted of the murder of Paul Castellano

(6, 1).clue: In 2013 Zagat named his Spago the most iconic restaurant in Los Angeles

(1, 2).clue: Works by this fatherly TV star, including "The Meanest Thing To Say", made the club in 1997

(2, 2).clue: In the early 1950s, Chevrolet PR exec Myron Scott came up with the idea of naming this 2-door for a type of fast warship

(3, 2).clue: Hyphenated appendage adjective for a frog or beaver

(4, 2).clue: In 1976 the scoreboard in Montreal didn't have enough spaces, so the perfect score of this gymnast read 1.00

(5, 2).clue: (The New York Times reporter Linda Greenhouse gives the clue.)  In a 1991 case I covered, the Supreme Court overturned a New York law aimed at preventing criminals from profiting by selling their stories--a law informally named for this 1970s killer

(6, 2).clue: While living in Paris, Julia Child was the only woman in her class at this famed cooking school

(1, 3).clue: For Book Club 2.0, Oprah chose "The Invention of Wings" by this author who once explored the secret life of bees

(2, 3).clue: This sporty Triumph convertible that debuted in 1962 shares its name with a classic British fighter plane

(3, 3).clue: A nickname for Spider-Man; it's also a toy you can buy to pretend to be him

(4, 3).clue: Sports Illustrated compared the 15-year rivalry of Chris Evert & this woman to Ali & Frazier

(5, 3).clue: The 1996 crash of this airline's flight 800 "broke the calm of a sultry summer evening...along the Long Island shore"

(6, 3).clue: In 2012 this Brit who brought his "food revolution" to America won the Harvard School of Public Health's Healthy Cup Award

(1, 4).clue: The club's 70 books in 15 years included this biblically titled book by Jane Hamilton

(2, 4).clue: Mazda introduced the sprightly MX5, aka this, in 1989

(3, 4).clue: Seen here is this diagram of ecological relations

(4, 4).clue: In 1923 Zev won the first & third legs of horse racing's Triple Crown but finished 12th in this race

(5, 4).clue: (The New York Times reporter James Risen gives the clue.)  In 1998 I reported on the deadly al-Qaeda bombings of U.S. embassies in these 2 neighboring African countries, a prelude to the worse attacks to follow

(6, 4).clue: Her dad was part of Thatcher's cabinet; she became Britain's "domestic goddess"

(1, 5).clue: Things got a little dicey after Oprah selected this maybe not-so-autobiographical James Frey memoir

(2, 5).clue: More than a "minor" success, this British car was born in a 2-door version in 1948

(3, 5).clue: 19th century treaty that settled the northern boundaries of Maine & Wisconsin

(4, 5).clue: The only position player to join baseball's Hall of Fame in 2014 is this 2-time MVP for the White Sox in the '90s

(5, 5).clue: "Accord reached to end the war in Bosnia" in a 1995 story datelined this midwest U.S. city

(6, 5).clue: This Frenchman who created the peach melba was known as "the king of chefs & the chef of kings"

(1, 1).clue: The Khongoryn Els, or "Singing Dunes", are a popular tourist destination in this Central Asian Desert

(2, 1).clue: Free yourself & tell us this Righteous Brothers song that was featured prominently in "Ghost"

(3, 1).clue: If you put off till tomorrow what you can do today, you're this type of person

(4, 1).clue: He said, "I wish to have no connection with any ship that does not sail fast, for I intend to go in harm's way"

(5, 1).clue: An astrobleme is a scar on the earth's surface from the impact of one of these

(6, 1).clue: 2004:Canadian Lorne Michaels took this "prize for American humor"

(1, 2).clue: This Russian lake, the world's deepest, plunges to 5,315 feet

(2, 2).clue: Songs in this marionette-populated movie included "Freedom Isn't Free" & "Kim Jong Il"

(3, 2).clue: Popular in the 1970s & '80s, they were largely replaced by DVDs

(4, 2).clue: In the early hours of April 19, 1775, minutemen gathered at this city's Buckman Tavern awaiting the Redcoats

(5, 2).clue: In the Compton Effect, light quanta, better known by this one-word name, transfer energy to electrons

(6, 2).clue: 1920:W.E.B. Du Bois medaled as winner No. 6

(1, 3).clue: This sultanate borders Saudi Arabia in the Rub Al Khali Desert

(2, 3).clue: Dressed in Amish garb, John Popper & this band close out "Kingpin" with "But Anyway"

(3, 3).clue: Profession of Nobel Prize winner Saul Perlmutter, who discovered that the universe is expanding at an accelerating rate

(4, 3).clue: On Dec. 16, 1773, members of this 8-year-old group left a meeting to board British ships & dump tea

(5, 3).clue: This genus is the most common bacterial cause of a sore throat

(1, 4).clue: Kotte, a suburb of this city, was once a capital of Sinhalese kings

(2, 4).clue: At the end of this David Lynch film, Nicolas Cage croons "Love Me Tender" to Laura Dern

(3, 4).clue: Pinkeye is a form of this eye inflammation

(4, 4).clue: This "New" city 20 miles from Newark served both the British & the Americans as a headquarters

(5, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew is with Team Oracle at the America's Cup in San Francisco.) The lower pressure at the front of the sail generates faster-moving air and allows a vessel to travel as fast as 2 1/2 times the wind that is driving it, a demonstration of the effect named for this Swiss physicist

(6, 4).clue: 1967:Arnold Schwarzenegger becomes a "star" for the first time

(1, 5).clue: This smallest Chinese province in area consists mostly of one island in the Gulf of Tonkin

(2, 5).clue: "We're gonna do what they say can't be done" is from this "Smokey & The Bandit" song, later an HBO sitcom title

(3, 5).clue: Brainwashing is a type of this, the process of teaching an ideology & making sure it sticks

(4, 5).clue: This British general who captured Fort Ticonderoga in 1777 later became a playwright

(5, 5).clue: The Mariana Trench is this type of zone, caused because the Pacific Plate is being pushed under the Philippine Plate

(6, 5).clue: 1983:I.M. Pei wins "the Nobel Prize of Architecture"

(0, 0).clue: In Genesis 4 this name is chosen because God "hath appointed me another seed"
